moves.1. d4 d5 2. c4 dxc4 3. e4 e6 4. Bxc4 Nc6: This was not such a great exchange--white gets a pawn and a knight in exchange for a bishop.
moves.11. Bxb5 axb5 12. Nxb5 Nxb4 13. Be3 Ba6: Now I'm thinking, bishop for rook?  Sounds great!
moves.15... Bxf1 16. Rxa8 Qxa8 17. Qxf1: Here I'm only up one point, but I have a queen and a rook against a queen.  I should swap queens and increase my material advantage.  But my left side is not well developed, and white has that one passed pawn.
moves.17... Ne7 18. b5 O-O 19. b6 Rb8 20. g4: I should move the knight to C6 to threaten the pawn.  Why don't I do this?
moves.20... Nc8: Oh, I did.  Well that was good thinking!
moves.21. g5 Nxb6 22. gxf6 gxf6 23. Bh6 Kf7 24: This was kind of stupid.  I hoped he would interpose his queen, but why would he when I'm forcing his king into a better position, while burying my queen in a useless far flung corner of the board.  Not one of my better ideas.
moves.25. Kg2 Rg8+ 26. Ng5+: Suddenly I realize that Ke7 or Ke8 will be followed by Qe6+.  Not pretty.  Kg6 exchanges the rook for white's knight--also unpleasant.  I decide to trade the rook (and a pawn) for the bishop and knight.  I actually conditional moved the entire sequence.
moves.26... Rxg5+ 27. Bxg5 fxg5 28. Qf5+: Except I had expected QxP7+.  I'm not sure what white thought his advantage would be with this move.
NxPd7 would be followed by QxQ, a disappointing result for black.  I opt for a series of checks.  If I can get my queen out of the way, Ne6 would fork white's queens. but this would be easily avoided by Qb6+ and the white queens frog march the black king up against the a wall.  Ugh!
moves.36... Qc2 37. d8=Q: Two girls for every boy.  Black may be able to snag a few pawns, but his king is paralyzed behind the white queens.
Here I examined what happens if black pushes the h passed pawn instead of checking the white king.  White forces mate in less than ten moves, deftly working around the black knight with a series of checks, beginning with Qa5+.
My goal is to badger white into a draw.
moves.49... Qb4+ 50. Kc2 Qb3+: White accepts.  Though were I playing white, I might have fought longer.  After examining the position from white's point of view, however, there doesn't appear to be any way to force a queen exchange.  Provided black makes no error, it really does look like a draw.
